bioAsHtml: After completing a Ph.D in experimental atomic physics, Xavier entered the field of data analysis, with projects in finance and then tackled bioinformatics challenges and software development for academic research for 10 years. During that time, he worked on genome annotation and visualisation, as well as prediction of RNA structure and interactions with genes. He developed and deployed a distributed storage system to share data between remote biotech platforms. Since leaving academia, he pursues his way, providing services and development in data analysis, embracing functional programming, Scala and BigData technologies.

acceptedTalks.summaryAsHtml: We are at a time where biotech allow us to get personal genomes for $1000. Tremendous progress since the 70s in DNA sequencing have been done, e.g. more samples in an experiment, more genomic coverages at higher speeds. Genomic analysis standards that have been developed over the years weren't designed with scalability and adaptability in mind. In this talk, we’ll present a game changing technology in this area, ADAM, initiated by the AMPLab at Berkeley. ADAM is framework based on Apache Spark and the Parquet storage. We’ll see how it can speed up a sequence reconstruction to a factor 150.
acceptedTalks.title: Scalable Genomics with ADAM
